transformed_texts:
Okay, so I think the Catholic Church needs to evolve a bit, you know? Like, I hear they're losing followers, and I think it might be because some of their views are, well, a little stuck in the past.  

Take gay marriage, abortion, birth control – these are hot button issues, and the Church's stance on them is pretty strong.  Now, they have the right to their beliefs, but maybe if they opened their minds a little, they wouldn't be losing so many people.  

I hear folks are starting to turn away from the Church because they disagree with how they handle these things.  It's like, if the Church says abortion is wrong and you believe it's okay, you might not feel comfortable being part of that group. Same with gay marriage – if that's something you support, you might not want to belong to a place that doesn't.

Honestly, I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to get married.  It's not like those things would magically solve all their problems, but maybe it would help.  Like, maybe if priests had families, they wouldn't be so quick to, you know, *do those things*.  I mean, it's hard to say for sure, right?

So, like, gay marriage, huh? Well, I ain't sayin' it's wrong, you know? I dunno, maybe it's somethin' you're just born with, like, not a choice, ya dig? Like, I was born straight, and some folks are born gay, right?  Seems kinda unfair to hold 'em responsible for somethin' they weren't choosin',  y'know?

It just seems messed up to me that a man and a woman can get hitched, but two dudes or two ladies can't.  Haven't really thought too hard about it, but it feels wrong,  ya know?

It's like, they don't get to pick who they're attracted to,  it's just how they are.  I mean, shouldn't we be cool with that? Shouldn't the government stay outta people's love lives?  It ain't like it's threatenin' national security or nothin'. Seems kinda private, y'know?

It's like, why put 'em on a stage and make 'em feel bad for  who they are? Like they made a wrong choice or somethin'.  Nah, man, that ain't right.  Let 'em live their lives,  love who they love,  it's not hurtin' nobody.

So, I'm all for gay marriage, ya know? There's really no good reason against it. Some folks think gay couples are gonna mess up straight families, but come on! It's just not the same thing.  It's like two sides of the same coin – different, but still connected.  

There's a whole bunch of rights that come with marriage, like property and healthcare. Think about it, if your partner's gay, they can't even visit you in the hospital! It's crazy, right? If you're gonna spend your life with someone, shouldn't they have those rights? 

Lots of studies show that gay relationships are just as strong and healthy as straight ones.  They've got the same ingredients for a happy relationship. It's just love, plain and simple.  

What bugs me is that folks get hung up on the religious angle.  Gay folks aren't asking to get married in a church – they just want a legal document, something the government issues.  If the government isn't involved in religion, why should it matter?

It's like segregation – separating people based on who they are isn't fair. Gay couples are just like straight couples – they have the same roles, the same dynamics.

People worry about adoption and kids. Will they be okay? But the truth is, parenting skills are the same, whether you're gay or straight.  It's about love and care, not orientation.  Plus, some kids of gay parents face bullying in schools. It's heartbreaking, and it shouldn't be happening.

Look, I think the government needs to step in and make gay marriage legal everywhere.  It's about equality and treating everyone fairly.  President Bush seems to have strong religious views that get in the way, but morality is subjective! It's not something the government should be dictating.  

Some folks think being gay is a psychological problem, but the American Psychological Association says that's just not true. We need to listen to experts and evidence, not just rumors and prejudice.

Alright, so listen up, I work in a hospital pharmacy, you know?  See, just 'cause something's illegal doesn't mean it's all bad. Like,  I think making drugs available to everyone is a big no-no, but for medical uses?  Totally a yes. Cause come on, just 'cause something's illegal doesn't mean it ain't got some good uses, right? It's not like it's inherently bad.  

I mean, think about it,  we pharmacies use all kinds of crazy drugs that are totally illegal, like OxyContin, Vicodin, Percocet, all that jazz. They're controlled substances, but we use 'em all the time 'cause they actually help people. So why not give marijuana the same chance, ya know? 

People get all hung up on it being taboo, but it ain't like alcohol. Sure, alcohol can be bad too, but weed, if you mess with it too much, it's not gonna kill ya like some hard stuff. It's a tricky thing, I guess. Maybe we should legalize it little by little, not all at once, so folks don't go crazy. But first, we gotta ditch that whole scary "Reefer Madness" vibe, ya know? 

People freak out about marijuana 'cause it's illegal, but honestly, it ain't as bad as heroin or cocaine.  If we stop picturing it as this evil drug, maybe people will use it responsibly. And for medical stuff?  Definitely.

So, I think the church has totally changed with the times, you know? It's not as strict as it used to be. When I was a kid, every Sunday was a big deal - cute dresses, matching shoes, the whole nine yards. I went to a private school, so all my friends were there too. We'd go to church every week, but now things are different. 

They've got this teen mass thing, which is only like thirty minutes long. People dress way more casual, especially in the summer. I've seen people show up straight from the beach! And even at the morning masses, where I used to get all dolled up, people are rocking jeans and khakis now.  

Honestly, that's the biggest change I've noticed. As for all the other stuff, like the scandals with priests, well, I don't really know about all that political stuff. But yeah, the church seems a lot more laid-back these days.

(laughs)

Man, where do I even begin? I mean, the whole Iraq thing just makes my blood boil. At first, I was kinda okay with the idea, but then 9/11 happened, and everything changed. It felt like we rushed into this war, using 9/11 as a smokescreen.

They kept saying Saddam Hussein was connected to Bin Laden and had weapons of mass destruction, but that's all been proven false. The Bush administration straight up lied to us, and they haven't even admitted it! It's like they don't even care about the Constitution.

I mean, even Colin Powell, remember that big speech he gave at the UN? Now he says he wasn't convinced by the evidence back then! That's just wrong. That's a crime, plain and simple.

It feels like they came into office wanting to go to war, and they twisted everything to make it happen. I heard this one guy, a former Treasury Secretary, said they were practically itching for a fight. And don't even get me started on the whole oil thing – using a war to control resources? So shady.

It's been going on for way too long. Pulling out now would be messy, though, probably cause a civil war and more deaths. But sending in Syria and Saudi Arabia to "fix" things? That doesn't feel right either. It's like they're just going to keep meddling in Iraq's affairs, and that's not good for anyone.

And the Iraqi government? What a mess! Parliament's useless, the Prime Minister has no real power, and these radical groups are running wild. It's like a powder keg waiting to explode.

My thoughts on the War in Iraq?  Man, it's a real head-scratcher. It feels kinda pointless, you know?  I mean, it wasn't even a real war, officially. It just felt like a "get back at Iraq" thing, like they were the ones behind 9/11. 

Honestly, I'm not really into politics or keeping up with all the details. But it seems like we're still there trying to build a democracy, like we want Iraq to become another USA. And, let's be real, oil is a big part of it too. 

The thing is, it's making everyone mad.  We can't just force democracy on them overnight. It takes time, and if we leave before it's set, they'll be even more messed up.  It's a real catch-22.

See, I'm not good with tough topics like this. It's so complicated! 

But I guess I feel like we should stay, help them out, but it's a waste of resources. It's making Bush look bad, kind of like how Vietnam is still seen as a bad thing.

On the other hand, I know there are families with loved ones in Iraq, and I don't want to see them hurt. 

It's a mess! They have their own culture, and we're trying to force ours on them. It just feels like it's making things worse, stirring up more hatred.

I think this war will drag on forever, and nobody wins in the end. It's a real bummer.

Ugh, I just can't see how legalizing it is right. It feels wrong, like the government overstepping its bounds. The Constitution, man, it's crystal clear about separating church and state. They're trying to force their beliefs on everyone, picking and choosing which churches get to decide what's right and wrong. It's like saying Catholics get to rule the roost on this one, even though most of them are against it.  

Separation of church and state is what makes this country great, you know? It lets everyone practice their faith freely.  Trying to change that with an amendment feels like going against everything the Constitution stands for. Plus, wouldn't it be the first amendment ever meant to restrict people instead of the government?  

This whole thing just feels off. The government shouldn't be telling churches what they can and can't do. It should be up to them, not some politician pushing his own beliefs, especially when they go against the grain of what the Constitution already says.  

I just don't see how it impacts the economy or anything else. Maybe even a positive vibe, who knows? It's all about personal choice, not government interference.

Okay, so the war in Iraq...  Let me tell ya, I don't think the government straight up told the American people the whole truth about why we went in there. They tried to tie it to the 9/11 attacks, but honestly, those two things weren't really connected. The government played on people's emotions, you know? They were angry after 9/11, and they used that anger to push for the invasion, which started in 2003. 

I'm totally against war, especially when it's a preemptive strike.  This whole Iraq thing feels a lot like Vietnam – another mistake the government should've learned from.  Tons of American soldiers have died, and it's heartbreaking.

They went in and just ripped out Iraq's government without a solid plan for what would happen next. They didn't think about the power vacuum, the chaos that would erupt. Now we're stuck there trying to put in a democracy, which is a tough job, even in a country that's ready for it.

It's like what happened in Vietnam – trying to push out communism and force democracy on a people who weren't ready for it. It wasn't a clear victory, more like a long, painful loss. You can't just win hearts and minds by force.  Even if some people support you, there are always going to be insurgents fighting back. It's impossible to fight a whole nation.

The government should've known this going in.  They should've planned for all the possibilities.  They made it seem like this would be a quick, clean win, but it's been dragging on forever.  We're still there in 2006, American troops are still dying, and the Iraqi government is still struggling to hold together.

It's a tough situation.  I mean, we can't just leave them now after all the chaos we've unleashed. But how long can we keep putting our own people at risk for a country that might never be truly free?

And then there's the whole oil thing. Are we really fighting this war for democracy, or are we fighting for access to their resources? We knew North Korea had weapons of mass destruction, and we didn't do anything about it. It's all about money and control, isn't it?

So, you know, I'm all for gay marriage, always have been.  I really think it's a personal preference, something that science is showing is more likely biological than anything else.  To take away someone's rights because of something they can't control, something that's part of who they are, feels just plain wrong to me. It's like, inhuman, you know? I've always been a supporter of gay marriage. 

I don't think politics or the government should have anything to do with it. This is a personal thing, a family thing. It's not something the state should be dictating. At home, in my neighborhood, there are a couple of gay couples who are together, but can't get married because the law won't let them. They live their lives just like any other family. They walk their dogs, they go to work, they're part of the community. 

It just seems ridiculous to me that Bush is trying to play God and decide what marriage means. It's people's lives, their love, their commitment.  

I've read and heard a lot about how studies are showing that there's a biological basis for being gay, something that's in your brain chemistry. It's like you're born that way, not something you choose. It's not about how you were raised or your environment. 

Besides the obvious,  it just feels… yeah, like it's a private matter. A guy and a girl can marry without anyone knowing, but if two gay people want to get married, it's a huge deal. It's like they're making a public spectacle out of it when it should just be a personal celebration.  It should be kept in the private realm, not splashed all over the news.

Alright, listen up. When you chuck something on the internet, it's like shouting it from the rooftops - everyone can hear it. It's public, plain and simple. 

Being an RA, I've seen this firsthand.  Whatever you put online, it sticks. People will judge you based on it. If you're talking about blowing stuff up or shooting things, someone's gonna freak out.  You can't just toss these things out there. The internet's a wild beast; everyone's got a peek. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, boom, you get their updates.

Now, the school probably didn't get an official warning from Myspace. Someone saw something, got worried, and told the school. They had to act, you know?  Imagine if something bad happened, and they could have stopped it?  

But, here's the catch - sometimes people mess around, right? They joke around, and it can get misinterpreted. Like, maybe it was just a crazed sociology project gone wrong. Or maybe, just maybe, it was something serious.

In this case, someone heard something at school, reported it, and the school investigated. They looked through the kid's Facebook, and found some stuff that, in light of the situation, was pretty darn scary. It might have been a joke, but it looked bad.

The thing is, once you put something online, there's no privacy. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it! Don't expect to control what people think.

Now, I'm not saying school officials should be stalking their students on Facebook. That's creepy! But if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously. 

I mean, I don't think they should be snooping through texts or IMs unless they have a good reason. But if something's brought up, they have to investigate.

It's a tricky situation.

Right, so I feel like this whole war has dragged on for far too long.  At the start, I get it, there was a good reason, right?  Helping another country get its democracy going.  But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that. Now it feels like we're just in it because we have to be, like we're trying to prove we're the big dogs.  Plus, the whole thing started because of, you know, whatever issues Bush Sr. had with Saddam back in the day. So maybe the reasons we started this weren't so pure to begin with.

If the goal was to bring democracy to a country that didn't have one, that's a good thing, a righteous thing. But I don't think that's what's happening anymore. It's like we've lost our way, and now it's all about winning, about not backing down, even though it's been going on for years.

Listen, maybe in those first few months, dropping that bombshell made a statement, but come on, it's been way too long.  Their government, their people, they have to figure things out on their own eventually. We can't keep throwing money and lives into this thing forever.

Think about it: we're spending billions and billions, money that could be helping people here at home.  We have our own problems, poverty, things we need to fix, but instead, we're pouring it all into this war that doesn't even have a clear purpose anymore.

We need to stop. We need to bring our troops home. There comes a point where you just have to say enough is enough. We can't keep bleeding money and lives for a war we've already lost.

So, lemme ask,  you know, there was this thing, right?  Seems like someone saw somethin' online, like on Myspace, and it, like, stopped some bad stuff from happening. I get that it's kind of a bummer, ya know, people lookin' at your stuff without permission. But isn't Myspace kinda public, like, if you put it out there, it's kinda fair game?

I mean, you gotta be friends with someone to see their profile, but you chose to be their friend, right?  So it's kinda like givin' them the okay to see that stuff.

It's like, anything you put online, you gotta expect that some folks might see it.

I guess if someone saw somethin' that could've saved someone's life, that's a good thing, right?

But,  uh, it's tough, right?  I mean, you can't have someone watchin' everyone's Myspace all day, lookin' for trouble.

That'd be like, pickin' on the "bad kids" or somethin'.

I don't know, maybe it depends on the situation.

Like, were they lookin' for somethin' specific, or just snoopin'?

I don't know, it's a sticky wicket.

Me, I don't have Myspace, but I got Facebook.

It freaks me out a little thinkin' about creeps out there seein' my stuff.

I saw this thing on TV once, about this dude who could find people's info real fast, like, got their screen name and started talkin' to 'em on IM in like, less than a minute, and got 'em to meet up.

I wouldn't do that, but I've had people in my classes IM'in me, and they know it's me, even though I don't recognize their names.

It's creepy, 'cause they know all about you, your classes, your friends, your photos. 

I try to keep it clean, but it's hard, 'cause Facebook is supposed to be for connectin' with friends.

So, it's a double-edged sword, ya know?

You put stuff out there, you gotta expect some folks might see it.

 I heard my roommate talkin' about her high school, they banned Myspace.

That's kinda weird, right? How can they tell you what you can and can't do online?

Ugh, this whole Iraq War thing makes me want to pull my hair out.  It feels hypocritical even talking about it, you know?  I hate jumping on the bandwagon of people who claim they were against it from the start.  I mean, I was, but honestly, does it even matter now?  It's like everyone knows it was a bad idea except for those in charge who just can't admit they messed up. 

You look at the polls, it's insane.  Everywhere you look, seventy-five to eighty percent of people think it was a disaster – Iraqis, Americans, even the troops over there.  They want out!  And who can blame them?  It's been a train wreck from day one, and pulling out is just gonna be another dumpster fire.  The Middle East is a tangled mess, and our culture just clashes so badly with theirs.  It's like these politicians think they can just force democracy on them, but it's not that simple.  It's their culture, their way of life, and it's not like they asked for our help.

Sure, Saddam was a jerk, no question.  But you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country, and this was just a recipe for disaster.  It's like quicksand, the deeper we get, the harder it is to get out.  

Honestly, I don't even know what to say anymore.  I can't see any reason to stay there, and I haven't heard a single good reason from the administration.  Maybe a slow pullout over a year or so wouldn't be so bad, but just leaving now?  I think the people of Iraq deserve a say in this, and if they want us gone, maybe we should listen.  At least then we can wash our hands of it and say, "We gave you the chance, but you chose to go your own way."

We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, no matter what we do.  But at least this way we'd be less of a problem.

Ya know what? I totally think gender discrimination is still a thing in the U.S., and it's not just about women. It's more like, depending on the field you're in, you know? Like for women, there's this invisible ceiling, even though equality is supposed to be a thing.  

Men sometimes have a hard time taking orders from a woman, just because of how things have always been. So, a woman might have all the qualifications for a job, but the board won't promote her because, well, history tells them women aren't supposed to be in charge. 

It's the same for guys, though, in other areas. Think about stay-at-home dads. It's super rare for a guy to be the one at home with the kids. People often judge them, thinking, "Shouldn't the man be out earning money?"  It can be tough on them when their dream is to raise their kids and their wife has the better job, even if it all works out great for their family. Society just doesn't get it. 

And in fashion? Guys can get overlooked if they're straight. Not sure if that makes sense, but people might think, "How can a guy *really* understand fashion if he's not a woman?" It's like, "Oh, you're not like the other guys, so you must not know what you're talking about."

So yeah, depending on what you do, there's definitely gender discrimination.  Changing it is slow, though. We've come a long way from the 1800s for sure, but people have set ways of thinking.  Slowly, women are climbing the corporate ladder, becoming CEOs, and being accepted in business.  More men are becoming stay-at-home dads, and people are starting to see that it can work.  

I think it's all about showing the good qualities of those who are stereotyped.  If you push too hard, people resist. We're finding a balance, but change takes time.

So, get this, they didn't exactly legalize it, more like took the handcuffs off, y'know? Demystified it, turned it from a full-blown criminal offense to, like, a parking ticket.  You get a slap on the wrist instead of being thrown in the slammer. But here's the kicker, man, even with this decriminalization thing, the fear of a drug charge still lingers. Job interviews, background checks, all that jazz. It's a shadow that follows you, even if you're not facing jail time.  

It's crazy, right?  Think about it, the system spends a fortune locking people up for weed.  Courts, lawyers, housing, the whole nine yards. Where's that money going? Could it be going towards, you know, helping people instead of punishing them?  

Seems like cities struggling financially could really use that cash. But then again, some places are just dead set against marijuana, no matter what. It's like a principle thing.

But in places like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, I think it's a win-win. More money for schools, social programs, helping those in need.  It's a step in the right direction. 

But let's be real, we don't want weed everywhere, blowing up like cigarettes in gas stations. There are valid concerns about that. It's still a bit taboo in many circles. Imagine the awkwardness, right? 

And alcohol, that's a different beast.  It messes with your motor skills more directly.  But marijuana, it can mess with your life in other ways, your choices, your priorities.  

It's a double-edged sword, man.  It affects everyone differently. Some people are responsible, some go overboard. It's hard to say for sure what the right answer is.

I reckon I'd say yes, mostly because a lot of their traditions are pretty solid, like they've been doing the same stuff for ages. That's cool, you know, having roots. But it's also gotta be alright to change with the times, right? 

See, a lot of Catholics I know feel this pressure to go to church every week, and there's a real strictness around how things are done. It's like they judge folks who don't follow every single rule perfectly. They don't seem too keen on folks who aren't, like, totally Catholic either, you know? And they don't really roll out the welcome mat for people from other religions.

For instance, my dad was an Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't let them get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion.  Talk about not being open-minded, right?  We were always taught to love everyone, which is a big Catholic thing. But it feels kinda bogus when they preach that and then don't even accept people who are different.

It's like, the rules say one thing, but the way things are actually done is totally different. It's all so stuck in the past, and they just cling to it even though it seems kinda outdated.  

Now, I think letting priests get married would be a good thing, but it probably wouldn't stop them from, you know, doing the bad stuff. It's a whole 'nother level, you know?

I mean, people who hurt kids, they probably gonna hurt kids regardless of whether they're married or not. It's about something messed up inside them, not about being single.  So, I don't think allowing priests to marry would stop that from happening.

Nope.

Ugh, man, this whole thing is a real head-scratcher. I'm not sure where I stand on it yet, you know? It's tough to say if either side is totally right or wrong. This feels like the biggest, most tangled mess we're dealing with right now. It's like walking a tightrope between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage even means.  It's a real minefield, trying to talk about this without stepping on anyone's toes.

I dunno, maybe... maybe all civil unions are the way to go.  Should the government even be in charge of defining marriage, anyway?  It's like a sacrament, right? People don't get special tax breaks or anything from the government just for being baptized. So, if you're married, maybe the government should just see it as a civil union - two people, that's all it is. No need to get into the whole church and state thing, just recognize that two people are together.

And with gay marriage...  I mean, it's just like any other civil union, right? Two people, love, commitment. If all the states could agree on that, maybe it should just become federal law.

But trying to change the Constitution to ban gay marriage? That's insane! The Constitution shouldn't be messed with just because some people feel strongly about something. It's a big deal for some folks, sure, but not big enough to change the foundation of our country. It just doesn't make sense.

Nope, not worth it.

Growing up in a Christian household, the topic of homosexuality is a bit complicated for me.  I've got tons of gay friends, you know? It's not something I totally agree with, but I believe everyone should have the right to marry who they love. It shouldn't be a national debate, though. I think each state should decide for themselves.

  Like, you've got your blue states and your red states, right?  Blue states tend to be more open to gay marriage, and if you live in one of those states, well, that's how they feel about it. It's their call. You kinda knew what you were getting into when you moved there.

 It's all about equal opportunity for everyone. Homosexuals deserve the same chances as anyone else, so legalizing it on a state-by-state basis seems fair.

 Honestly, I don't think the president should have the power to ban gay marriage across the whole country. It's up to the states to decide what's best for their own people. 

Look, Bush is leaving office soon anyway. What happens then? If a new president comes in and wants to change things, it'll just be back and forth forever. Let each state figure it out for themselves. They're the ones who have to live with the consequences, not the president.

Okay, so, like, Myspace is a public thing, right? It's like a bulletin board where everyone can see what you post. If you put something on there, you gotta know that people will see it - teachers, parents, even the principal.

So, if the school sees something on Myspace that worries them, like talk about a potential shooting, they have a right to see it. Even if they weren't looking under the school's name, they could easily find it from home. 

I get that it's creepy for them to snoop, especially if they're just looking for reasons to punish kids for drinking or smoking. But if they're trying to prevent something really bad, like a school shooting, then I think it's okay. Schools have a responsibility to keep students safe, right?

It's just like with emails. You wouldn't write something bad about someone in an email if you didn't want them to see it, right? Because once something is online, it's out there forever.  

It's scary to think that something you post online could come back to bite you later, like when you're an adult. People can find old stuff from your Myspace days, even if you thought you deleted it. 

So, yeah, I think it's a bit of a gray area. On one hand, it's a invasion of privacy. On the other hand, they're trying to keep everyone safe.

Alright, so, the war... man.  At first, I was all in, you know?  Nine Eleven hit close to home, and I wanted payback.  I was ready to cause some serious chaos, just like they did here.  But looking back, I think we were fueled by emotion.  We didn't really think things through, went in unprepared, without a plan.  And it blew up in our faces.  I mean, I was for it then, but now?  I'm completely against it.

I don't think it accomplished anything.  Those people over there, they're always fighting amongst themselves.  If they can't even get along, how are we supposed to help?  Frankly, Nine Eleven kinda made me lose all care about what happens over there.

They're just... different, you know?  They fight like savages, and I don't think they're really aiming to improve their country. They just want us out.  And honestly, maybe that's best.  We should just pack up and leave.  We were just hyped up, driven by revenge.  Bush felt the pressure, the people wanted action.  And yeah, I get it, declaring war on Iraq seemed like the only option after what happened.

But we needed a better plan.  We didn't know what we were facing, and war over there is different.  We lacked unity, no clear goals, and it just spiraled out of control.  We went in driven by anger, and that's what we created over there.  I don't think we're capable of changing them. They're always going to be like that.

I've said enough.  It's gone on long enough.  Sure, we've made some progress, but not enough to justify staying.  They'll just collapse once we leave, and we can't stay forever.  We're hurting ourselves by staying.

transformed_texts:
Okay, so I think the Catholic Church needs to evolve a bit, you know? Like, I hear they're losing followers, and I think it might be because some of their views are, well, a little stuck in the past.  

Take gay marriage, abortion, birth control – these are hot button issues, and the Church's stance on them is pretty strong.  Now, they have the right to their beliefs, but maybe if they opened their minds a little, they wouldn't be losing so many people.  

I hear folks are starting to turn away from the Church because they disagree with how they handle these things.  It's like, if the Church says abortion is wrong and you believe it's okay, you might not feel comfortable being part of that group. Same with gay marriage – if that's something you support, you might not want to belong to a place that doesn't.

Honestly, I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to get married.  It's not like those things would magically solve all their problems, but maybe it would help.  Like, maybe if priests had families, they wouldn't be so quick to, you know, *do those things*.  I mean, it's hard to say for sure, right?

So, like, gay marriage, huh? Well, I ain't sayin' it's wrong, you know? I dunno, maybe it's somethin' you're just born with, like, not a choice, ya dig? Like, I was born straight, and some folks are born gay, right?  Seems kinda unfair to hold 'em responsible for somethin' they weren't choosin',  y'know?

It just seems messed up to me that a man and a woman can get hitched, but two dudes or two ladies can't.  Haven't really thought too hard about it, but it feels wrong,  ya know?

It's like, they don't get to pick who they're attracted to,  it's just how they are.  I mean, shouldn't we be cool with that? Shouldn't the government stay outta people's love lives?  It ain't like it's threatenin' national security or nothin'. Seems kinda private, y'know?

It's like, why put 'em on a stage and make 'em feel bad for  who they are? Like they made a wrong choice or somethin'.  Nah, man, that ain't right.  Let 'em live their lives,  love who they love,  it's not hurtin' nobody.

So, I'm all for gay marriage, ya know? There's really no good reason against it. Some folks think gay couples are gonna mess up straight families, but come on! It's just not the same thing.  It's like two sides of the same coin – different, but still connected.  

There's a whole bunch of rights that come with marriage, like property and healthcare. Think about it, if your partner's gay, they can't even visit you in the hospital! It's crazy, right? If you're gonna spend your life with someone, shouldn't they have those rights? 

Lots of studies show that gay relationships are just as strong and healthy as straight ones.  They've got the same ingredients for a happy relationship. It's just love, plain and simple.  

What bugs me is that folks get hung up on the religious angle.  Gay folks aren't asking to get married in a church – they just want a legal document, something the government issues.  If the government isn't involved in religion, why should it matter?

It's like segregation – separating people based on who they are isn't fair. Gay couples are just like straight couples – they have the same roles, the same dynamics.

People worry about adoption and kids. Will they be okay? But the truth is, parenting skills are the same, whether you're gay or straight.  It's about love and care, not orientation.  Plus, some kids of gay parents face bullying in schools. It's heartbreaking, and it shouldn't be happening.

Look, I think the government needs to step in and make gay marriage legal everywhere.  It's about equality and treating everyone fairly.  President Bush seems to have strong religious views that get in the way, but morality is subjective! It's not something the government should be dictating.  

Some folks think being gay is a psychological problem, but the American Psychological Association says that's just not true. We need to listen to experts and evidence, not just rumors and prejudice.

Alright, so listen up, I work in a hospital pharmacy, you know?  See, just 'cause something's illegal doesn't mean it's all bad. Like,  I think making drugs available to everyone is a big no-no, but for medical uses?  Totally a yes. Cause come on, just 'cause something's illegal doesn't mean it ain't got some good uses, right? It's not like it's inherently bad.  

I mean, think about it,  we pharmacies use all kinds of crazy drugs that are totally illegal, like OxyContin, Vicodin, Percocet, all that jazz. They're controlled substances, but we use 'em all the time 'cause they actually help people. So why not give marijuana the same chance, ya know? 

People get all hung up on it being taboo, but it ain't like alcohol. Sure, alcohol can be bad too, but weed, if you mess with it too much, it's not gonna kill ya like some hard stuff. It's a tricky thing, I guess. Maybe we should legalize it little by little, not all at once, so folks don't go crazy. But first, we gotta ditch that whole scary "Reefer Madness" vibe, ya know? 

People freak out about marijuana 'cause it's illegal, but honestly, it ain't as bad as heroin or cocaine.  If we stop picturing it as this evil drug, maybe people will use it responsibly. And for medical stuff?  Definitely.

So, I think the church has totally changed with the times, you know? It's not as strict as it used to be. When I was a kid, every Sunday was a big deal - cute dresses, matching shoes, the whole nine yards. I went to a private school, so all my friends were there too. We'd go to church every week, but now things are different. 

They've got this teen mass thing, which is only like thirty minutes long. People dress way more casual, especially in the summer. I've seen people show up straight from the beach! And even at the morning masses, where I used to get all dolled up, people are rocking jeans and khakis now.  

Honestly, that's the biggest change I've noticed. As for all the other stuff, like the scandals with priests, well, I don't really know about all that political stuff. But yeah, the church seems a lot more laid-back these days.

(laughs)

Man, where do I even begin? I mean, the whole Iraq thing just makes my blood boil. At first, I was kinda okay with the idea, but then 9/11 happened, and everything changed. It felt like we rushed into this war, using 9/11 as a smokescreen.

They kept saying Saddam Hussein was connected to Bin Laden and had weapons of mass destruction, but that's all been proven false. The Bush administration straight up lied to us, and they haven't even admitted it! It's like they don't even care about the Constitution.

I mean, even Colin Powell, remember that big speech he gave at the UN? Now he says he wasn't convinced by the evidence back then! That's just wrong. That's a crime, plain and simple.

It feels like they came into office wanting to go to war, and they twisted everything to make it happen. I heard this one guy, a former Treasury Secretary, said they were practically itching for a fight. And don't even get me started on the whole oil thing – using a war to control resources? So shady.

It's been going on for way too long. Pulling out now would be messy, though, probably cause a civil war and more deaths. But sending in Syria and Saudi Arabia to "fix" things? That doesn't feel right either. It's like they're just going to keep meddling in Iraq's affairs, and that's not good for anyone.

And the Iraqi government? What a mess! Parliament's useless, the Prime Minister has no real power, and these radical groups are running wild. It's like a powder keg waiting to explode.

My thoughts on the War in Iraq?  Man, it's a real head-scratcher. It feels kinda pointless, you know?  I mean, it wasn't even a real war, officially. It just felt like a "get back at Iraq" thing, like they were the ones behind 9/11. 

Honestly, I'm not really into politics or keeping up with all the details. But it seems like we're still there trying to build a democracy, like we want Iraq to become another USA. And, let's be real, oil is a big part of it too. 

The thing is, it's making everyone mad.  We can't just force democracy on them overnight. It takes time, and if we leave before it's set, they'll be even more messed up.  It's a real catch-22.

See, I'm not good with tough topics like this. It's so complicated! 

But I guess I feel like we should stay, help them out, but it's a waste of resources. It's making Bush look bad, kind of like how Vietnam is still seen as a bad thing.

On the other hand, I know there are families with loved ones in Iraq, and I don't want to see them hurt. 

It's a mess! They have their own culture, and we're trying to force ours on them. It just feels like it's making things worse, stirring up more hatred.

I think this war will drag on forever, and nobody wins in the end. It's a real bummer.

Ugh, I just can't see how legalizing it is right. It feels wrong, like the government overstepping its bounds. The Constitution, man, it's crystal clear about separating church and state. They're trying to force their beliefs on everyone, picking and choosing which churches get to decide what's right and wrong. It's like saying Catholics get to rule the roost on this one, even though most of them are against it.  

Separation of church and state is what makes this country great, you know? It lets everyone practice their faith freely.  Trying to change that with an amendment feels like going against everything the Constitution stands for. Plus, wouldn't it be the first amendment ever meant to restrict people instead of the government?  

This whole thing just feels off. The government shouldn't be telling churches what they can and can't do. It should be up to them, not some politician pushing his own beliefs, especially when they go against the grain of what the Constitution already says.  

I just don't see how it impacts the economy or anything else. Maybe even a positive vibe, who knows? It's all about personal choice, not government interference.

Okay, so the war in Iraq...  Let me tell ya, I don't think the government straight up told the American people the whole truth about why we went in there. They tried to tie it to the 9/11 attacks, but honestly, those two things weren't really connected. The government played on people's emotions, you know? They were angry after 9/11, and they used that anger to push for the invasion, which started in 2003. 

I'm totally against war, especially when it's a preemptive strike.  This whole Iraq thing feels a lot like Vietnam – another mistake the government should've learned from.  Tons of American soldiers have died, and it's heartbreaking.

They went in and just ripped out Iraq's government without a solid plan for what would happen next. They didn't think about the power vacuum, the chaos that would erupt. Now we're stuck there trying to put in a democracy, which is a tough job, even in a country that's ready for it.

It's like what happened in Vietnam – trying to push out communism and force democracy on a people who weren't ready for it. It wasn't a clear victory, more like a long, painful loss. You can't just win hearts and minds by force.  Even if some people support you, there are always going to be insurgents fighting back. It's impossible to fight a whole nation.

The government should've known this going in.  They should've planned for all the possibilities.  They made it seem like this would be a quick, clean win, but it's been dragging on forever.  We're still there in 2006, American troops are still dying, and the Iraqi government is still struggling to hold together.

It's a tough situation.  I mean, we can't just leave them now after all the chaos we've unleashed. But how long can we keep putting our own people at risk for a country that might never be truly free?

And then there's the whole oil thing. Are we really fighting this war for democracy, or are we fighting for access to their resources? We knew North Korea had weapons of mass destruction, and we didn't do anything about it. It's all about money and control, isn't it?

So, you know, I'm all for gay marriage, always have been.  I really think it's a personal preference, something that science is showing is more likely biological than anything else.  To take away someone's rights because of something they can't control, something that's part of who they are, feels just plain wrong to me. It's like, inhuman, you know? I've always been a supporter of gay marriage. 

I don't think politics or the government should have anything to do with it. This is a personal thing, a family thing. It's not something the state should be dictating. At home, in my neighborhood, there are a couple of gay couples who are together, but can't get married because the law won't let them. They live their lives just like any other family. They walk their dogs, they go to work, they're part of the community. 

It just seems ridiculous to me that Bush is trying to play God and decide what marriage means. It's people's lives, their love, their commitment.  

I've read and heard a lot about how studies are showing that there's a biological basis for being gay, something that's in your brain chemistry. It's like you're born that way, not something you choose. It's not about how you were raised or your environment. 

Besides the obvious,  it just feels… yeah, like it's a private matter. A guy and a girl can marry without anyone knowing, but if two gay people want to get married, it's a huge deal. It's like they're making a public spectacle out of it when it should just be a personal celebration.  It should be kept in the private realm, not splashed all over the news.

Alright, listen up. When you chuck something on the internet, it's like shouting it from the rooftops - everyone can hear it. It's public, plain and simple. 

Being an RA, I've seen this firsthand.  Whatever you put online, it sticks. People will judge you based on it. If you're talking about blowing stuff up or shooting things, someone's gonna freak out.  You can't just toss these things out there. The internet's a wild beast; everyone's got a peek. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, boom, you get their updates.

Now, the school probably didn't get an official warning from Myspace. Someone saw something, got worried, and told the school. They had to act, you know?  Imagine if something bad happened, and they could have stopped it?  

But, here's the catch - sometimes people mess around, right? They joke around, and it can get misinterpreted. Like, maybe it was just a crazed sociology project gone wrong. Or maybe, just maybe, it was something serious.

In this case, someone heard something at school, reported it, and the school investigated. They looked through the kid's Facebook, and found some stuff that, in light of the situation, was pretty darn scary. It might have been a joke, but it looked bad.

The thing is, once you put something online, there's no privacy. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it! Don't expect to control what people think.

Now, I'm not saying school officials should be stalking their students on Facebook. That's creepy! But if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously. 

I mean, I don't think they should be snooping through texts or IMs unless they have a good reason. But if something's brought up, they have to investigate.

It's a tricky situation.

Right, so I feel like this whole war has dragged on for far too long.  At the start, I get it, there was a good reason, right?  Helping another country get its democracy going.  But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that. Now it feels like we're just in it because we have to be, like we're trying to prove we're the big dogs.  Plus, the whole thing started because of, you know, whatever issues Bush Sr. had with Saddam back in the day. So maybe the reasons we started this weren't so pure to begin with.

If the goal was to bring democracy to a country that didn't have one, that's a good thing, a righteous thing. But I don't think that's what's happening anymore. It's like we've lost our way, and now it's all about winning, about not backing down, even though it's been going on for years.

Listen, maybe in those first few months, dropping that bombshell made a statement, but come on, it's been way too long.  Their government, their people, they have to figure things out on their own eventually. We can't keep throwing money and lives into this thing forever.

Think about it: we're spending billions and billions, money that could be helping people here at home.  We have our own problems, poverty, things we need to fix, but instead, we're pouring it all into this war that doesn't even have a clear purpose anymore.

We need to stop. We need to bring our troops home. There comes a point where you just have to say enough is enough. We can't keep bleeding money and lives for a war we've already lost.

So, lemme ask,  you know, there was this thing, right?  Seems like someone saw somethin' online, like on Myspace, and it, like, stopped some bad stuff from happening. I get that it's kind of a bummer, ya know, people lookin' at your stuff without permission. But isn't Myspace kinda public, like, if you put it out there, it's kinda fair game?

I mean, you gotta be friends with someone to see their profile, but you chose to be their friend, right?  So it's kinda like givin' them the okay to see that stuff.

It's like, anything you put online, you gotta expect that some folks might see it.

I guess if someone saw somethin' that could've saved someone's life, that's a good thing, right?

But,  uh, it's tough, right?  I mean, you can't have someone watchin' everyone's Myspace all day, lookin' for trouble.

That'd be like, pickin' on the "bad kids" or somethin'.

I don't know, maybe it depends on the situation.

Like, were they lookin' for somethin' specific, or just snoopin'?

I don't know, it's a sticky wicket.

Me, I don't have Myspace, but I got Facebook.

It freaks me out a little thinkin' about creeps out there seein' my stuff.

I saw this thing on TV once, about this dude who could find people's info real fast, like, got their screen name and started talkin' to 'em on IM in like, less than a minute, and got 'em to meet up.

I wouldn't do that, but I've had people in my classes IM'in me, and they know it's me, even though I don't recognize their names.

It's creepy, 'cause they know all about you, your classes, your friends, your photos. 

I try to keep it clean, but it's hard, 'cause Facebook is supposed to be for connectin' with friends.

So, it's a double-edged sword, ya know?

You put stuff out there, you gotta expect some folks might see it.

 I heard my roommate talkin' about her high school, they banned Myspace.

That's kinda weird, right? How can they tell you what you can and can't do online?

Ugh, this whole Iraq War thing makes me want to pull my hair out.  It feels hypocritical even talking about it, you know?  I hate jumping on the bandwagon of people who claim they were against it from the start.  I mean, I was, but honestly, does it even matter now?  It's like everyone knows it was a bad idea except for those in charge who just can't admit they messed up. 

You look at the polls, it's insane.  Everywhere you look, seventy-five to eighty percent of people think it was a disaster – Iraqis, Americans, even the troops over there.  They want out!  And who can blame them?  It's been a train wreck from day one, and pulling out is just gonna be another dumpster fire.  The Middle East is a tangled mess, and our culture just clashes so badly with theirs.  It's like these politicians think they can just force democracy on them, but it's not that simple.  It's their culture, their way of life, and it's not like they asked for our help.

Sure, Saddam was a jerk, no question.  But you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country, and this was just a recipe for disaster.  It's like quicksand, the deeper we get, the harder it is to get out.  

Honestly, I don't even know what to say anymore.  I can't see any reason to stay there, and I haven't heard a single good reason from the administration.  Maybe a slow pullout over a year or so wouldn't be so bad, but just leaving now?  I think the people of Iraq deserve a say in this, and if they want us gone, maybe we should listen.  At least then we can wash our hands of it and say, "We gave you the chance, but you chose to go your own way."

We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, no matter what we do.  But at least this way we'd be less of a problem.

Ya know what? I totally think gender discrimination is still a thing in the U.S., and it's not just about women. It's more like, depending on the field you're in, you know? Like for women, there's this invisible ceiling, even though equality is supposed to be a thing.  

Men sometimes have a hard time taking orders from a woman, just because of how things have always been. So, a woman might have all the qualifications for a job, but the board won't promote her because, well, history tells them women aren't supposed to be in charge. 

It's the same for guys, though, in other areas. Think about stay-at-home dads. It's super rare for a guy to be the one at home with the kids. People often judge them, thinking, "Shouldn't the man be out earning money?"  It can be tough on them when their dream is to raise their kids and their wife has the better job, even if it all works out great for their family. Society just doesn't get it. 

And in fashion? Guys can get overlooked if they're straight. Not sure if that makes sense, but people might think, "How can a guy *really* understand fashion if he's not a woman?" It's like, "Oh, you're not like the other guys, so you must not know what you're talking about."

So yeah, depending on what you do, there's definitely gender discrimination.  Changing it is slow, though. We've come a long way from the 1800s for sure, but people have set ways of thinking.  Slowly, women are climbing the corporate ladder, becoming CEOs, and being accepted in business.  More men are becoming stay-at-home dads, and people are starting to see that it can work.  

I think it's all about showing the good qualities of those who are stereotyped.  If you push too hard, people resist. We're finding a balance, but change takes time.

So, get this, they didn't exactly legalize it, more like took the handcuffs off, y'know? Demystified it, turned it from a full-blown criminal offense to, like, a parking ticket.  You get a slap on the wrist instead of being thrown in the slammer. But here's the kicker, man, even with this decriminalization thing, the fear of a drug charge still lingers. Job interviews, background checks, all that jazz. It's a shadow that follows you, even if you're not facing jail time.  

It's crazy, right?  Think about it, the system spends a fortune locking people up for weed.  Courts, lawyers, housing, the whole nine yards. Where's that money going? Could it be going towards, you know, helping people instead of punishing them?  

Seems like cities struggling financially could really use that cash. But then again, some places are just dead set against marijuana, no matter what. It's like a principle thing.

But in places like Denver, where folks are a bit more open-minded, I think it's a win-win. More money for schools, social programs, helping those in need.  It's a step in the right direction. 

But let's be real, we don't want weed everywhere, blowing up like cigarettes in gas stations. There are valid concerns about that. It's still a bit taboo in many circles. Imagine the awkwardness, right? 

And alcohol, that's a different beast.  It messes with your motor skills more directly.  But marijuana, it can mess with your life in other ways, your choices, your priorities.  

It's a double-edged sword, man.  It affects everyone differently. Some people are responsible, some go overboard. It's hard to say for sure what the right answer is.

I reckon I'd say yes, mostly because a lot of their traditions are pretty solid, like they've been doing the same stuff for ages. That's cool, you know, having roots. But it's also gotta be alright to change with the times, right? 

See, a lot of Catholics I know feel this pressure to go to church every week, and there's a real strictness around how things are done. It's like they judge folks who don't follow every single rule perfectly. They don't seem too keen on folks who aren't, like, totally Catholic either, you know? And they don't really roll out the welcome mat for people from other religions.

For instance, my dad was an Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't let them get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion.  Talk about not being open-minded, right?  We were always taught to love everyone, which is a big Catholic thing. But it feels kinda bogus when they preach that and then don't even accept people who are different.

It's like, the rules say one thing, but the way things are actually done is totally different. It's all so stuck in the past, and they just cling to it even though it seems kinda outdated.  

Now, I think letting priests get married would be a good thing, but it probably wouldn't stop them from, you know, doing the bad stuff. It's a whole 'nother level, you know?

I mean, people who hurt kids, they probably gonna hurt kids regardless of whether they're married or not. It's about something messed up inside them, not about being single.  So, I don't think allowing priests to marry would stop that from happening.

Nope.

Ugh, man, this whole thing is a real head-scratcher. I'm not sure where I stand on it yet, you know? It's tough to say if either side is totally right or wrong. This feels like the biggest, most tangled mess we're dealing with right now. It's like walking a tightrope between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage even means.  It's a real minefield, trying to talk about this without stepping on anyone's toes.

I dunno, maybe... maybe all civil unions are the way to go.  Should the government even be in charge of defining marriage, anyway?  It's like a sacrament, right? People don't get special tax breaks or anything from the government just for being baptized. So, if you're married, maybe the government should just see it as a civil union - two people, that's all it is. No need to get into the whole church and state thing, just recognize that two people are together.

And with gay marriage...  I mean, it's just like any other civil union, right? Two people, love, commitment. If all the states could agree on that, maybe it should just become federal law.

But trying to change the Constitution to ban gay marriage? That's insane! The Constitution shouldn't be messed with just because some people feel strongly about something. It's a big deal for some folks, sure, but not big enough to change the foundation of our country. It just doesn't make sense.

Nope, not worth it.

Growing up in a Christian household, the topic of homosexuality is a bit complicated for me.  I've got tons of gay friends, you know? It's not something I totally agree with, but I believe everyone should have the right to marry who they love. It shouldn't be a national debate, though. I think each state should decide for themselves.

  Like, you've got your blue states and your red states, right?  Blue states tend to be more open to gay marriage, and if you live in one of those states, well, that's how they feel about it. It's their call. You kinda knew what you were getting into when you moved there.

 It's all about equal opportunity for everyone. Homosexuals deserve the same chances as anyone else, so legalizing it on a state-by-state basis seems fair.

 Honestly, I don't think the president should have the power to ban gay marriage across the whole country. It's up to the states to decide what's best for their own people. 

Look, Bush is leaving office soon anyway. What happens then? If a new president comes in and wants to change things, it'll just be back and forth forever. Let each state figure it out for themselves. They're the ones who have to live with the consequences, not the president.

Okay, so, like, Myspace is a public thing, right? It's like a bulletin board where everyone can see what you post. If you put something on there, you gotta know that people will see it - teachers, parents, even the principal.

So, if the school sees something on Myspace that worries them, like talk about a potential shooting, they have a right to see it. Even if they weren't looking under the school's name, they could easily find it from home. 

I get that it's creepy for them to snoop, especially if they're just looking for reasons to punish kids for drinking or smoking. But if they're trying to prevent something really bad, like a school shooting, then I think it's okay. Schools have a responsibility to keep students safe, right?

It's just like with emails. You wouldn't write something bad about someone in an email if you didn't want them to see it, right? Because once something is online, it's out there forever.  

It's scary to think that something you post online could come back to bite you later, like when you're an adult. People can find old stuff from your Myspace days, even if you thought you deleted it. 

So, yeah, I think it's a bit of a gray area. On one hand, it's a invasion of privacy. On the other hand, they're trying to keep everyone safe.

Alright, so, the war... man.  At first, I was all in, you know?  Nine Eleven hit close to home, and I wanted payback.  I was ready to cause some serious chaos, just like they did here.  But looking back, I think we were fueled by emotion.  We didn't really think things through, went in unprepared, without a plan.  And it blew up in our faces.  I mean, I was for it then, but now?  I'm completely against it.

I don't think it accomplished anything.  Those people over there, they're always fighting amongst themselves.  If they can't even get along, how are we supposed to help?  Frankly, Nine Eleven kinda made me lose all care about what happens over there.

They're just... different, you know?  They fight like savages, and I don't think they're really aiming to improve their country. They just want us out.  And honestly, maybe that's best.  We should just pack up and leave.  We were just hyped up, driven by revenge.  Bush felt the pressure, the people wanted action.  And yeah, I get it, declaring war on Iraq seemed like the only option after what happened.

But we needed a better plan.  We didn't know what we were facing, and war over there is different.  We lacked unity, no clear goals, and it just spiraled out of control.  We went in driven by anger, and that's what we created over there.  I don't think we're capable of changing them. They're always going to be like that.

I've said enough.  It's gone on long enough.  Sure, we've made some progress, but not enough to justify staying.  They'll just collapse once we leave, and we can't stay forever.  We're hurting ourselves by staying.
