transformed_texts:
You know, I feel like the Catholic Church could really use a bit of an update, ya know?  

They've been going on about how they're losing followers, and I think it's 'cause they're not super accepting of, well, a lot of stuff. Like, take gay marriage, abortion, birth control - those are biggies. They've got these super strong opinions about 'em, which is cool, but some of it feels a bit stuck in the past, ya know?  

I've heard that a lot of people are starting to ditch the church 'cause they don't agree with their views on these things.  They just feel like the Church is on the wrong side of things. 

Like, if you believe in abortion rights, you might not feel comfortable being part of a church that says it's completely wrong.  Same deal with gay marriage, if that's something you support, you might not wanna be in a church that doesn't.

Honestly, I don't see why they can't have female priests or married priests.  But I'm not sure if that would've stopped all the bad stuff that's gone down. 

It's tough to say, right? Maybe they would have done things differently if they could've gotten married or had women priests, but who knows? 

I just think it's weird that priests are supposed to be devoted to God but can't have regular lives with families like everyone else.  They're human too!

Alright, so, like, gay marriage, huh? I'm not against it, you know? I think, like, whether you're born that way or whatever, it's not like a choice you make on purpose, right? So, gay people shouldn't be blamed for who they are, you know? It's messed up to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't.  

I haven't really thought about it too much, but yeah, it seems wrong to me. Like, it's not a choice, you're just born that way. I mean, I was born straight, and someone else is born gay, right? It's not something you pick, so you shouldn't be punished for it, if you get what I mean.

(clears throat)

Yeah, I definitely think it's wrong. I don't think the government should be involved, 'cause it's not really a legal thing, or even really a moral issue, you know? I mean, gay people shouldn't be put on trial or anything, like they made a wrong choice.

It's not the government's business, you know?

(laughs)

It's tough to explain, but, like, it's not about security or morals or anything. It's just people's lives, and they should be able to live how they want. They shouldn't be punished for who they are. That's just how they were born, and that's okay.

Okay, so I'm totally for gay marriage, you know?  It just seems like there's no good reason to say no.  People worry that it'll mess up traditional families, but honestly, it's like comparing apples and oranges.  They're different, but both relationships are, like, the same thing under the surface. It's just love, right?

There's a ton of legal stuff too. Like, if you're in a gay couple, your partner can't even be in the hospital room with you if you're sick!  It's crazy because they're not considered family.  And who else would you want there if you're really sick?

Plus, there's a bunch of research showing that gay couples are just as happy and successful as straight couples. They have the same things that make relationships work. It's all about the connection, you know?

What really gets me is that people think this is about churches getting involved. It's not! Gay couples aren't asking to get married in a church, they just want a legal document from the government.  The church and the state should be separate, right?

And it's like, if you're okay with civil unions, why not just go all the way with marriage? It's the same thing, just with a different name.  It's like segregation, but for love.  

People worry about adoption and how it will affect kids, but honestly, it's just about being a good parent.  Gay couples can be just as loving and caring as straight couples.

The problem is that sometimes kids get bullied or treated differently because their parents are gay. It's sad, but it happens.

I think the government should definitely get involved and make gay marriage legal everywhere. It shouldn't be up to each state to decide. 

The whole thing makes me mad, especially when you hear people saying it goes against their religion.  It's like, how can they decide what's right for everyone else based on their beliefs? 

And don't even get me started on the idea that being gay is a choice or a problem. That's just not true! The American Psychological Association has said that being gay is normal and healthy. People just need to open their minds and hearts to the truth.

Listen, I work the pharmacy counter at a hospital, see?  Just 'cause a medicine ain't legal doesn't mean it's all bad, y'know?  I mean, should folks be able to just walk in and grab it? Nope, not a chance. But if it can help someone, I'm all for it.  I mean, a medicine's not evil just 'cause it's outlawed, right?

Think about it: we use stuff like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet in the pharmacy all the time. They're super strong, controlled, but they help folks feel better. So why slam the door on weed just 'cause it's got a bad rap?  Embrace the good parts, right?

Now, I ain't saying it's exactly like booze.  Both can be messy if you overdo it, but...  It's a tough call. Maybe ease into it, you know? Make it legal bit by bit, not all at once.  Gotta break down that wall of fear around weed first.  Then folks might treat it with respect, not like some devilish demon.

People freak out 'cause it's illegal, but c'mon,  it ain't heroin or coke. It ain't that bad for you.  If we ditch the scary stories, maybe folks'll use it smart, especially for when they're sick.

Y'know, I feel like the church has really changed with the times. It's not as strict as it used to be,  not even close.  When I was a kid, going to church every Sunday was a big deal. I'd rock the cutest dresses, matching shoes, the whole nine yards!  We went to a private school, so all my friends were there too, every single weekend.  But now things are different. They've got this "teenager mass", all thirty minutes long, and people dress way more casual.  Especially in the summer, you'd see folks in their beach gear, straight from the sand! Families would rush in late, no biggie.  Even the morning masses, where I used to get all dolled up, now folks are rocking jeans and khakis. Don't get me wrong, khakis are fine, but it's definitely more laid-back.

That's the biggest change I've noticed. As far as the church itself goes, that's all I really know. I don't get into the church politics or anything like that.

Speaking of politics, I heard about all the nasty stuff going on with priests and kids.  It makes me sick. Do you think things would have been different if the church allowed female priests or let priests get married?

I don't think so. Some married guys become pedophiles anyway, they've got that urge no matter what.  I think it's something inside them, not about being married or not.  And choosing to become a priest is their own decision.  There are other religions where priests can get married, like on that show "Seventh Heaven". They're ministers or whatever, but they can have families. If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should look into a different church.

I think it's all about genetics, like, some folks are just born with those urges. You can't change that with marriage, it might hide it for a while, but it'll probably come out eventually.  I don't think the church could have stopped this from happening, but if they knew and covered it up, shame on them!

(laughs) 
Man, that whole Iraq thing just makes my blood boil.  I mean, at first, I wasn't totally against the idea, but everyone was still reeling from 9/11, you know? It felt like we were jumping into a war based on some pretty shaky pretexts. The Bush administration kept linking Iraq to Bin Laden and those 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction.  We all know now that was a load of crap.  

I just can't stand how the Bush guys flat out lied to the American people. It's like they have zero respect for the truth, and even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN, admitted later he wasn't convinced by the evidence back then. That's malfeasance, plain and simple.  An impeachable offense, if you ask me.  

It feels like they came into office with a war on their minds, wanting to make a statement. There was even talk, after that Secretary of the Treasury guy got kicked out, about how younger Bush had a personal grudge against Saddam Hussein because of his dad.  I mean, what a mess.  And let's not forget about the whole energy thing - like it's all about securing oil, y'know?  Pretty slimy. 

Look, it's gone on for way too long.  Pulling out now would be a disaster, though.  Iraq could easily spiral into civil war, and even more people would die. The UN is trying to put together some kind of coalition from the region - Syria, Saudi Arabia, that sort of thing - but I'm not sure that's the best idea either. It's gonna mess with Iraq's sovereignty, and we're already seeing problems with the government. The Parliament is a joke, and the Prime Minister doesn't seem to be in control.  And then there's al-Sadr and all those other factions fighting for power. It's a recipe for disaster.

(laughs)

You know, this whole War in Iraq thing, it's a real head-scratcher. It feels kinda pointless, like we just went in there because we thought Iraq was behind 9/11, you know?  I'm not one to get all worked up about war stuff, but it just doesn't sit right with me.  We're supposedly there to build democracy and grab some oil, but honestly, it's making everyone miserable.  Trying to force democracy on a place that's not ready for it is like trying to teach a toddler calculus.  It just ain't gonna happen overnight.  And if we leave, they'll probably blame us for messing everything up. It's a real catch-22.

I feel bad for Bush, too. This whole thing is making him look like one of those presidents people remember for all the wrong reasons, like the Vietnam War president.  It's heavy stuff.

Of course, there are those families with loved ones over there, and I don't want them to be stuck in danger. But at the same time, I just feel like we're not helping them.  We're changing their culture, forcing our way of life on them. That's just gonna make things worse.

This whole thing is a mess, and I don't think there's an easy solution. It feels like it's gonna drag on for years and years, and I just hope it doesn't make things even worse in the end.

Ugh, it just feels wrong to think about the government making something legal or illegal, especially something like this. It's all about the separation of church and state, right? The Constitution is super clear about that – it's right there in black and white.  Trying to push laws on this stuff feels like going against what's already been decided.

Plus, it's like picking one church's beliefs over another's. Most Catholics and Christians are against this, except for maybe in a few places like Boston.  Shouldn't it be up to the churches themselves to decide?  

Separation of church and state is a big deal in the US, it's all about letting people practice their religions freely. Even though they talked about adding an amendment, I think that's a bad idea. It goes against what's already in the Constitution, and it'd be weird – it's one of the few amendments that would restrict people instead of the government.

Honestly, the government shouldn't be involved at all.  This guy pushing for it just seems like he wants to enforce his own Catholic beliefs on everyone else. It's not fair to favor one religion over others. This is something the churches should decide, not the president or any government officials. There's no real reason to ban it, it doesn't hurt the economy or anything else – it might even make things better.

The whole Iraq war is just a mess, you know? Right from the start, I don't think the government was straight with us about why they wanted to invade. They tried to tie it all to 9/11, making it seem like Iraq was behind it, but that just wasn't true. They used our anger and fear after 9/11 to push us into war, and it all started back in 2003. 

I'm totally against war, especially when it's a preemptive strike, and this whole thing feels a lot like Vietnam. We should have learned from the mistakes we made there. We've lost so many good American soldiers, and for what? They went in, overthrew the Iraqi government, didn't have a plan for what to do next, and now look at the chaos. It's like they thought they could just drop in, install a democracy, and everything would be sunshine and rainbows.  

They're trying to do the same thing they did in Vietnam, pushing their idea of democracy onto a country that wasn't ready for it. It's a tough fight, especially when you're not fighting a regular army, but the people themselves. You can't just conquer a country and expect everyone to be happy about it. 

The government didn't plan for the aftermath. They didn't think about the power vacuum, the violence, the rebuilding. We're still there in 2006, with American troops still dying, trying to train the Iraqi army and police. It's a long, hard process, and I don't think the US government was honest with the American people about how long it would take or how difficult it would be. 

They made it seem easy, like a quick victory, but it's not that simple. Building a democracy takes time, and it takes a lot of work. Look at our own country, it took years of struggle to get to where we are now.  

I think we should have never gone to war in the first place. But if we did, we should have been prepared for everything. It's just sad that so many lives have been lost, and it's not clear if anything good will come out of it in the end.

Okay, so lemme tell ya, I'm all for gay marriage, always have been.  It just feels like a personal thing, y'know? Kinda like, who are we to decide what's right for someone else?  And, you know, science is showing more and more that it might even be biological, not just something you choose. It's like, how can you deny someone rights because of something they can't control?  Seems kinda messed up to me.  I've always been a big supporter of gay marriage.

It's not the government's business, either. It's a personal thing, between two people, not some big political deal.  Like, in my neighborhood, there are a couple of openly gay couples who are just trying to live their lives, but they can't even get married because, well, you know. They're just like any other family, walking their dogs, going about their business.  It's crazy to me that someone like Bush is trying to play God and decide what marriage means. 

I mean, I've read stuff, seen it on TV, that suggests it might even be in your genes, you know?  Maybe you're just born that way, not because of anything you did growing up.  It's not like choosing to have chocolate ice cream over vanilla. 

It's just... the whole thing feels unfair.  A guy and a girl can get married anytime, no big deal. But two guys or two girls, it's like front-page news!  It should be a private thing, not some public spectacle.

Okay, so, here's the deal. When you chuck something online, it's like shouting it from the rooftops.  It's out there for everyone to see.  As an RA, I've had to deal with this before.  Once you put something out there, it shapes how people see you.  If you're talking about blowing stuff up or shootings, someone's gonna freak out. You can't just toss that into the digital world and expect it to disappear.  The internet's a giant town square, everyone's checking it out.  Your friends on Myspace get those updates, right? It's not like the school magically got a bulletin, someone brought it to their attention.  They have to take action because, you know, what if something actually happens?  They could be blamed for not doing anything.

The tricky part is, you never know what's serious and what's just someone messing around.  It could be a social experiment gone wrong, like that sociology class I heard about, or it could be something really, really bad.  

In this case, someone overheard something at school, reported it, and the school investigated.  They looked at the kid's Facebook because someone was worried about some stuff he posted.  It might have seemed like a joke to him, but given the situation, it became a serious issue.

Bottom line, when you put stuff online, there's no real privacy anymore.  If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there.  You can't control what people think or take seriously.  

I don't think school officials should be friending their students on MySpace and Facebook, stalking their profiles, or snooping through their LiveJournals.  But if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously.   They shouldn't be monitoring phone calls and texts, but if it comes up, it's a whole different story.

Basically, don't be posting stuff online that you wouldn't want your grandma to see.

Right, so, I feel like this whole war thing has dragged on way too long. I get that at first, we had good intentions, you know, wanting to bring democracy to a place that didn't have it.  But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that.  Now it feels like we're just doing it to prove how powerful we are, like a big "look at us!" kinda thing.  

Plus, it makes me wonder about those original motives, especially with all the baggage between Bush Sr. and Saddam Hussein.  If the goal was to bring democracy to a place ruled by a dictator, that would be a good reason to go to war. But if there was any personal stuff mixed in, that's not cool.  

I think we made a pretty big statement in the beginning, showing everyone we weren't messing around. But after all these years – years! – I just don't see the point anymore. It feels like we're stuck in this endless cycle of fighting, just for the sake of fighting.  

We need a clear end to this, a win, or something. We can't just keep throwing money at a war that's lost its purpose.  We gotta think about our own problems too, you know?  Billions are going overseas when we have poverty, education issues, healthcare…things that need fixing right here at home.  

It's like we're pouring money into this bottomless pit while our own citizens are struggling. It's just not right.  

War shouldn't be a long-term budget item. We need to focus on fixing things here, supporting our people, and not wasting money on a war that's gone on for far too long.

So, there's this question about privacy on Myspace, right? 
Like, what happens when someone looks at your profile and finds something that could, you know, get someone hurt?
I mean, if you post stuff online, it's kinda out there for anyone to see. Like, on Myspace, you gotta be friends with someone to see their profile, but you're choosing to be their friend, so you're giving them permission to see it.

It's a weird situation though, 'cause you can't have someone watching everyone's profiles all the time, right? 
It'd be like picking on the "bad kids" just because they're online. 

But then again, what if someone was looking for something specific?
Like, if they saw something that made them think someone was in danger, wouldn't it be good they found it?

It's a tough call.  I don't have Myspace myself, but I have Facebook, and it freaks me out knowing that creepy people can see my stuff.
I saw this thing on TV where this guy showed how easy it was to find someone's info online. He got a girl's screen name and was chatting with her on IM within a minute, then got her to meet up.
I wouldn't do that, but some people in my classes message me on Facebook even though I don't recognize their names. They already know stuff about me, like my classes, my friends, and even pictures.

It's a bit scary, 'cause you think they know a lot about you. You try to be careful about what you post, but you also want to connect with friends.  It's a balancing act.

I heard my roommate talking about how her high school banned Myspace, which seems kinda messed up.  How can they tell students what they can and can't do online?

Ugh, this whole Iraq War thing just makes me feel so conflicted. It's hard to talk about it without feeling hypocritical, you know? Like, I hate jumping on the bandwagon of people who are all "I was against it from the start."  But honestly, it's just so obvious now that it was a terrible idea.  Everyone knows it, except for those stuck in the administration who can't admit they were wrong. 

I mean, look at the polls!  Everywhere you look –  the US, Iraq, even globally –  people are saying it was a bad call.  Seventy-five to eighty percent think it was a mistake. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of our own troops over there – they all agree it's time to get out.

It's been a mess from the beginning, and pulling out is just going to be another disaster.  There's no easy answer when it comes to the Middle East. It's like a cultural clash, you know? The US and the Middle East are just too different.  This administration, and the ones before it, think they can just force democracy on a place that's not ready for it.  It's like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole.

Sure, Saddam was a bad guy, but invading a country like that has consequences.  It's like quicksand – once you're in, it's hard to get out.

I don't know what to say about it anymore. I see no reason to stay. The administration probably has some fancy reasons why we should stick it out, but I haven't heard anything convincing. If they want to leave gradually, over a year or so, I guess I wouldn't be against it.  But honestly, we should just pull out now. 

I read that eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone within a year, and a quarter of them want us out right now. These are the people we're supposedly saving, trying to help. They're telling us to leave. Maybe they know what's best. At least if we ask them and they say "yes," then we're not to blame if things go south. We'll be like, "Hey, you guys wanted us out."

We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, no matter what we do. But at least leaving would be better than where we are now.

Yeah, listen, I totally think gender stuff is still a big deal in the U.S.  And it's not just about women, either. It's more about the field you're in, you know? Like, overall, I feel women have it tougher. There's this invisible ceiling, even though equality is supposed to be a thing. Sometimes guys get hung up on having a woman as their boss.  Society's been like that for ages! 

So, often women see a job they're totally qualified for, but the board might not pick them because, historically, women aren't seen as top dogs in business.  

It's the same for guys, though, in different ways. Think about staying home with kids. It's super uncommon for dads to be the stay-at-home parent, and people often judge them for it. Society thinks, "Dude, you gotta be the breadwinner, man!" Even if it's working great for them and the wife has the better job, people still look down on it.

And in fashion?  It's tough for straight guys. People might not take them seriously.  Maybe it's because guys into fashion are seen as having a different kind of lifestyle, so folks wonder if they really get "woman" fashion.  

So yeah, I think there's gender discrimination everywhere, depending on what you do. 

Changing it is slow, though. Society's got its ways, and we've definitely come a long way from the 1800s. But change is slow.  We're seeing more women in top roles, more dads at home, and people are slowly getting used to it. It's a process.

I think we just gotta keep promoting the good stuff about people who are stereotyped, not be too pushy. Just show them being awesome, you know?  If you force it, people resist.  We're starting to find a good balance.

Change takes time, man.

So, lemme break this down. They didn't exactly *legalize* it, more like decriminalized it, y'know?  Like, instead of being a full-blown criminal offense, it's more like,  uh, a traffic ticket.  You get a citation, not locked up in the slammer. It's a lighter slap on the wrist.  But, even with that, think about job interviews, background checks - all that jazz. Those kind of repercussions, they still linger, even if it ain't a hardcore criminal charge.  I mean, people worry about that future baggage, especially with something like marijuana. 

The thing is, cops and courts cost a pretty penny.  Arrest, booking, holding cells, court appearances, a lawyer, the whole shebang. It's a money pit!  And towns struggling financially? They're less likely to change their tune, even if it means saving cash in the long run.  I get it, some places are still dead set against marijuana, even if it's just about the bottom line.

Now, Denver's a different story.  They're more open-minded, you know, liberal, whatever word you wanna use.  Makes sense to me.  If they're raking in the dough from somewhere else, maybe they can use it for schools, help out seniors, feed the homeless folks.  Seems like a win-win, right?

Look, I'm not saying we should just let folks blaze up everywhere, in gas stations and whatnot.  There's a line. But the money thing is real.  Plus, it's still kinda taboo, you know?  Imagine everyone just smoking openly, it'd be awkward af.

Now, alcohol's got its own nasty side effects, I ain't denying it.  But marijuana, it messes with people's lives more, y'know?  It's not just about motor skills, it's about the whole vibe.

But honestly, everyone reacts differently.  Some folks can handle it, others, not so much.  It's a tricky thing.

I'd say "maybe" to the Catholic Church.  I mean, there's a lot to like about their traditions, they've been doing things the same way for ages, right? It's good to have roots, but it's also important to be able to change with the times.

The thing is, a lot of Catholics seem to think they *have* to go to church every week, and they're pretty strict about how things are done. Sometimes it feels like the Church judges people who don't follow the rules perfectly, and they don't really welcome people who aren't, well, *perfectly* Catholic.  They don't seem very open to other religions either. 

Take my dad, for example. He was an Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't even let them get married in the Catholic Church because of his religion! I mean, isn't loving others one of the biggest Catholic teachings? It seems hypocritical to preach love but then not accept people who are different. 

It's like they tell you to do one thing but then act another way entirely.  Their practices seem so stuck in the past, but they just keep holding on. 

Would allowing priests to marry change things? I personally think it would be a good idea, but I don't think it would stop them from, you know...doing bad things. It's a whole different issue, really.  

It's probably not the marriage that's the problem.  People who hurt kids would probably find a way to do it whether they were married or not. It's just a messed up thing to do.

Man, this whole thing about marriage is a real head-scratcher, you know? I haven't figured out where I stand yet.  It's like walking a tightrope between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage *really* means. It's a minefield,  Trying to nail down a definition without stepping on anyone's toes is tough.

I'm thinking, maybe all civil unions should just be treated the same.  If it's a sacrament, like baptism, the government shouldn't be in the business of giving tax breaks or special treatment based on it.  It's just two people coming together, right?  They shouldn't care if it's a religious ceremony or not.

And with gay marriage, I mean, it just seems like it should be a civil union thing.  Two people, one union.  Simple as that.

Now, if all the states can agree on something sensible,  then maybe it should become federal law. But this whole idea of a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage?  That's just crazy talk! The constitution shouldn't be changed just because some folks are really passionate about it.  It's not like it's a matter of life and death.

Growing up in a Christian household, my views on homosexuality are a bit complicated.  I've got a ton of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily condone their lifestyle, I think everyone should have the right to marry whoever they love.  It's not an issue that should be decided nationally, though. Each state should have the freedom to choose its own stance.  

Think about it: some states are more liberal, others are more conservative.  Democratic states are more likely to support gay marriage, and if you live there, you're pretty much accepting of that.  It's like choosing to live somewhere – you kinda know what to expect.

So, I believe everyone should have equal opportunities, regardless of their sexual orientation.  Legalizing gay marriage should be left up to each state to decide.  Personally, I don't think the president should have the power to impose his views on the entire country. It's not his place to dictate what happens in every state. 

Plus, he's leaving office soon anyway.  If a new president comes in and wants to overturn the ban, it'll just be a back-and-forth battle.  It's best to let each state decide what's right for them – they're the ones who have to live with the consequences.

Um, so basically, I'm saying MySpace is like a public bulletin board. Anything you put on there is meant for everyone to see, not just your friends. You gotta realize that if you post something online, even if it's not under your school's name, anyone can find it, even school officials at home.

So, yeah, I think it's totally fine if they saw something on there that could prevent a school shooting.  I mean, keeping students safe is, like, the school's responsibility, right?  

Now, I get it, if they're constantly snooping through MySpace just to catch kids doing dumb stuff, that's a different story. That's an invasion of privacy. But if they have a reason to believe something bad might happen, I think they're totally justified in looking.

It's kinda like, you wouldn't expect to get away with writing something bad about someone in a school hallway and not getting in trouble, right?  Same kinda thing with the internet.  Everything you post online can come back to bite you later, especially when you're older. 

The bottom line is, if posting on MySpace could save lives or make school a safer place, I think it's worth it. Like, imagine if they saw something that stopped a Columbine situation from happening.  That's gotta be worth it, right?

Ok, so about this whole war thing... see, after nine eleven, I was all for it.  You know, getting back at them, causing some serious chaos. I was riding high on that emotional wave, and honestly, I think we all kind of overlooked the big picture. We just jumped in, unprepared, with no real plan. And now? Well, now I think it backfired spectacularly. I mean, I used to be all for it, but now, I'm totally against it. 

It feels like we haven't accomplished anything.  The people over there, they're stuck fighting amongst themselves.  What good are we doing by being there if they can't even get along with each other?  I'm not saying it's not a tragedy, but I just feel numb about it now.   Truthfully, because of nine eleven, I just don't care about what goes on over there with those people. They're just fighting, tearing each other apart... it's like they don't even care about their own country. 

We went in there blind, clueless about what we were facing. War for them is different, way different from how we experience it. They're savage, and I don't think they're trying to build anything, they just want us out.  And honestly, maybe that's fine. Maybe we should just leave.

We were so hyped up, so caught up in the revenge thing, that we didn't think things through.  We just wanted to lash out, and I think Bush felt pressured to go to war because that's what people wanted.  He probably felt like he had no choice. 

But looking back, I think we should have had a better plan. We didn't know what we were doing, there was no clear strategy. It felt like we lacked unity, like we didn't even know why we were there.  

It was all emotion, anger... and that's what we created over there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change them. They'll always be like that. And at this point, I don't know if we're making enough progress to justify staying. We're hurting ourselves more than anything.  We can't stay there forever.

transformed_texts:
You know, I feel like the Catholic Church could really use a bit of an update, ya know?  

They've been going on about how they're losing followers, and I think it's 'cause they're not super accepting of, well, a lot of stuff. Like, take gay marriage, abortion, birth control - those are biggies. They've got these super strong opinions about 'em, which is cool, but some of it feels a bit stuck in the past, ya know?  

I've heard that a lot of people are starting to ditch the church 'cause they don't agree with their views on these things.  They just feel like the Church is on the wrong side of things. 

Like, if you believe in abortion rights, you might not feel comfortable being part of a church that says it's completely wrong.  Same deal with gay marriage, if that's something you support, you might not wanna be in a church that doesn't.

Honestly, I don't see why they can't have female priests or married priests.  But I'm not sure if that would've stopped all the bad stuff that's gone down. 

It's tough to say, right? Maybe they would have done things differently if they could've gotten married or had women priests, but who knows? 

I just think it's weird that priests are supposed to be devoted to God but can't have regular lives with families like everyone else.  They're human too!

Alright, so, like, gay marriage, huh? I'm not against it, you know? I think, like, whether you're born that way or whatever, it's not like a choice you make on purpose, right? So, gay people shouldn't be blamed for who they are, you know? It's messed up to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't.  

I haven't really thought about it too much, but yeah, it seems wrong to me. Like, it's not a choice, you're just born that way. I mean, I was born straight, and someone else is born gay, right? It's not something you pick, so you shouldn't be punished for it, if you get what I mean.

(clears throat)

Yeah, I definitely think it's wrong. I don't think the government should be involved, 'cause it's not really a legal thing, or even really a moral issue, you know? I mean, gay people shouldn't be put on trial or anything, like they made a wrong choice.

It's not the government's business, you know?

(laughs)

It's tough to explain, but, like, it's not about security or morals or anything. It's just people's lives, and they should be able to live how they want. They shouldn't be punished for who they are. That's just how they were born, and that's okay.

Okay, so I'm totally for gay marriage, you know?  It just seems like there's no good reason to say no.  People worry that it'll mess up traditional families, but honestly, it's like comparing apples and oranges.  They're different, but both relationships are, like, the same thing under the surface. It's just love, right?

There's a ton of legal stuff too. Like, if you're in a gay couple, your partner can't even be in the hospital room with you if you're sick!  It's crazy because they're not considered family.  And who else would you want there if you're really sick?

Plus, there's a bunch of research showing that gay couples are just as happy and successful as straight couples. They have the same things that make relationships work. It's all about the connection, you know?

What really gets me is that people think this is about churches getting involved. It's not! Gay couples aren't asking to get married in a church, they just want a legal document from the government.  The church and the state should be separate, right?

And it's like, if you're okay with civil unions, why not just go all the way with marriage? It's the same thing, just with a different name.  It's like segregation, but for love.  

People worry about adoption and how it will affect kids, but honestly, it's just about being a good parent.  Gay couples can be just as loving and caring as straight couples.

The problem is that sometimes kids get bullied or treated differently because their parents are gay. It's sad, but it happens.

I think the government should definitely get involved and make gay marriage legal everywhere. It shouldn't be up to each state to decide. 

The whole thing makes me mad, especially when you hear people saying it goes against their religion.  It's like, how can they decide what's right for everyone else based on their beliefs? 

And don't even get me started on the idea that being gay is a choice or a problem. That's just not true! The American Psychological Association has said that being gay is normal and healthy. People just need to open their minds and hearts to the truth.

Listen, I work the pharmacy counter at a hospital, see?  Just 'cause a medicine ain't legal doesn't mean it's all bad, y'know?  I mean, should folks be able to just walk in and grab it? Nope, not a chance. But if it can help someone, I'm all for it.  I mean, a medicine's not evil just 'cause it's outlawed, right?

Think about it: we use stuff like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet in the pharmacy all the time. They're super strong, controlled, but they help folks feel better. So why slam the door on weed just 'cause it's got a bad rap?  Embrace the good parts, right?

Now, I ain't saying it's exactly like booze.  Both can be messy if you overdo it, but...  It's a tough call. Maybe ease into it, you know? Make it legal bit by bit, not all at once.  Gotta break down that wall of fear around weed first.  Then folks might treat it with respect, not like some devilish demon.

People freak out 'cause it's illegal, but c'mon,  it ain't heroin or coke. It ain't that bad for you.  If we ditch the scary stories, maybe folks'll use it smart, especially for when they're sick.

Y'know, I feel like the church has really changed with the times. It's not as strict as it used to be,  not even close.  When I was a kid, going to church every Sunday was a big deal. I'd rock the cutest dresses, matching shoes, the whole nine yards!  We went to a private school, so all my friends were there too, every single weekend.  But now things are different. They've got this "teenager mass", all thirty minutes long, and people dress way more casual.  Especially in the summer, you'd see folks in their beach gear, straight from the sand! Families would rush in late, no biggie.  Even the morning masses, where I used to get all dolled up, now folks are rocking jeans and khakis. Don't get me wrong, khakis are fine, but it's definitely more laid-back.

That's the biggest change I've noticed. As far as the church itself goes, that's all I really know. I don't get into the church politics or anything like that.

Speaking of politics, I heard about all the nasty stuff going on with priests and kids.  It makes me sick. Do you think things would have been different if the church allowed female priests or let priests get married?

I don't think so. Some married guys become pedophiles anyway, they've got that urge no matter what.  I think it's something inside them, not about being married or not.  And choosing to become a priest is their own decision.  There are other religions where priests can get married, like on that show "Seventh Heaven". They're ministers or whatever, but they can have families. If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should look into a different church.

I think it's all about genetics, like, some folks are just born with those urges. You can't change that with marriage, it might hide it for a while, but it'll probably come out eventually.  I don't think the church could have stopped this from happening, but if they knew and covered it up, shame on them!

(laughs) 
Man, that whole Iraq thing just makes my blood boil.  I mean, at first, I wasn't totally against the idea, but everyone was still reeling from 9/11, you know? It felt like we were jumping into a war based on some pretty shaky pretexts. The Bush administration kept linking Iraq to Bin Laden and those 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction.  We all know now that was a load of crap.  

I just can't stand how the Bush guys flat out lied to the American people. It's like they have zero respect for the truth, and even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN, admitted later he wasn't convinced by the evidence back then. That's malfeasance, plain and simple.  An impeachable offense, if you ask me.  

It feels like they came into office with a war on their minds, wanting to make a statement. There was even talk, after that Secretary of the Treasury guy got kicked out, about how younger Bush had a personal grudge against Saddam Hussein because of his dad.  I mean, what a mess.  And let's not forget about the whole energy thing - like it's all about securing oil, y'know?  Pretty slimy. 

Look, it's gone on for way too long.  Pulling out now would be a disaster, though.  Iraq could easily spiral into civil war, and even more people would die. The UN is trying to put together some kind of coalition from the region - Syria, Saudi Arabia, that sort of thing - but I'm not sure that's the best idea either. It's gonna mess with Iraq's sovereignty, and we're already seeing problems with the government. The Parliament is a joke, and the Prime Minister doesn't seem to be in control.  And then there's al-Sadr and all those other factions fighting for power. It's a recipe for disaster.

(laughs)

You know, this whole War in Iraq thing, it's a real head-scratcher. It feels kinda pointless, like we just went in there because we thought Iraq was behind 9/11, you know?  I'm not one to get all worked up about war stuff, but it just doesn't sit right with me.  We're supposedly there to build democracy and grab some oil, but honestly, it's making everyone miserable.  Trying to force democracy on a place that's not ready for it is like trying to teach a toddler calculus.  It just ain't gonna happen overnight.  And if we leave, they'll probably blame us for messing everything up. It's a real catch-22.

I feel bad for Bush, too. This whole thing is making him look like one of those presidents people remember for all the wrong reasons, like the Vietnam War president.  It's heavy stuff.

Of course, there are those families with loved ones over there, and I don't want them to be stuck in danger. But at the same time, I just feel like we're not helping them.  We're changing their culture, forcing our way of life on them. That's just gonna make things worse.

This whole thing is a mess, and I don't think there's an easy solution. It feels like it's gonna drag on for years and years, and I just hope it doesn't make things even worse in the end.

Ugh, it just feels wrong to think about the government making something legal or illegal, especially something like this. It's all about the separation of church and state, right? The Constitution is super clear about that – it's right there in black and white.  Trying to push laws on this stuff feels like going against what's already been decided.

Plus, it's like picking one church's beliefs over another's. Most Catholics and Christians are against this, except for maybe in a few places like Boston.  Shouldn't it be up to the churches themselves to decide?  

Separation of church and state is a big deal in the US, it's all about letting people practice their religions freely. Even though they talked about adding an amendment, I think that's a bad idea. It goes against what's already in the Constitution, and it'd be weird – it's one of the few amendments that would restrict people instead of the government.

Honestly, the government shouldn't be involved at all.  This guy pushing for it just seems like he wants to enforce his own Catholic beliefs on everyone else. It's not fair to favor one religion over others. This is something the churches should decide, not the president or any government officials. There's no real reason to ban it, it doesn't hurt the economy or anything else – it might even make things better.

The whole Iraq war is just a mess, you know? Right from the start, I don't think the government was straight with us about why they wanted to invade. They tried to tie it all to 9/11, making it seem like Iraq was behind it, but that just wasn't true. They used our anger and fear after 9/11 to push us into war, and it all started back in 2003. 

I'm totally against war, especially when it's a preemptive strike, and this whole thing feels a lot like Vietnam. We should have learned from the mistakes we made there. We've lost so many good American soldiers, and for what? They went in, overthrew the Iraqi government, didn't have a plan for what to do next, and now look at the chaos. It's like they thought they could just drop in, install a democracy, and everything would be sunshine and rainbows.  

They're trying to do the same thing they did in Vietnam, pushing their idea of democracy onto a country that wasn't ready for it. It's a tough fight, especially when you're not fighting a regular army, but the people themselves. You can't just conquer a country and expect everyone to be happy about it. 

The government didn't plan for the aftermath. They didn't think about the power vacuum, the violence, the rebuilding. We're still there in 2006, with American troops still dying, trying to train the Iraqi army and police. It's a long, hard process, and I don't think the US government was honest with the American people about how long it would take or how difficult it would be. 

They made it seem easy, like a quick victory, but it's not that simple. Building a democracy takes time, and it takes a lot of work. Look at our own country, it took years of struggle to get to where we are now.  

I think we should have never gone to war in the first place. But if we did, we should have been prepared for everything. It's just sad that so many lives have been lost, and it's not clear if anything good will come out of it in the end.

Okay, so lemme tell ya, I'm all for gay marriage, always have been.  It just feels like a personal thing, y'know? Kinda like, who are we to decide what's right for someone else?  And, you know, science is showing more and more that it might even be biological, not just something you choose. It's like, how can you deny someone rights because of something they can't control?  Seems kinda messed up to me.  I've always been a big supporter of gay marriage.

It's not the government's business, either. It's a personal thing, between two people, not some big political deal.  Like, in my neighborhood, there are a couple of openly gay couples who are just trying to live their lives, but they can't even get married because, well, you know. They're just like any other family, walking their dogs, going about their business.  It's crazy to me that someone like Bush is trying to play God and decide what marriage means. 

I mean, I've read stuff, seen it on TV, that suggests it might even be in your genes, you know?  Maybe you're just born that way, not because of anything you did growing up.  It's not like choosing to have chocolate ice cream over vanilla. 

It's just... the whole thing feels unfair.  A guy and a girl can get married anytime, no big deal. But two guys or two girls, it's like front-page news!  It should be a private thing, not some public spectacle.

Okay, so, here's the deal. When you chuck something online, it's like shouting it from the rooftops.  It's out there for everyone to see.  As an RA, I've had to deal with this before.  Once you put something out there, it shapes how people see you.  If you're talking about blowing stuff up or shootings, someone's gonna freak out. You can't just toss that into the digital world and expect it to disappear.  The internet's a giant town square, everyone's checking it out.  Your friends on Myspace get those updates, right? It's not like the school magically got a bulletin, someone brought it to their attention.  They have to take action because, you know, what if something actually happens?  They could be blamed for not doing anything.

The tricky part is, you never know what's serious and what's just someone messing around.  It could be a social experiment gone wrong, like that sociology class I heard about, or it could be something really, really bad.  

In this case, someone overheard something at school, reported it, and the school investigated.  They looked at the kid's Facebook because someone was worried about some stuff he posted.  It might have seemed like a joke to him, but given the situation, it became a serious issue.

Bottom line, when you put stuff online, there's no real privacy anymore.  If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there.  You can't control what people think or take seriously.  

I don't think school officials should be friending their students on MySpace and Facebook, stalking their profiles, or snooping through their LiveJournals.  But if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously.   They shouldn't be monitoring phone calls and texts, but if it comes up, it's a whole different story.

Basically, don't be posting stuff online that you wouldn't want your grandma to see.

Right, so, I feel like this whole war thing has dragged on way too long. I get that at first, we had good intentions, you know, wanting to bring democracy to a place that didn't have it.  But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that.  Now it feels like we're just doing it to prove how powerful we are, like a big "look at us!" kinda thing.  

Plus, it makes me wonder about those original motives, especially with all the baggage between Bush Sr. and Saddam Hussein.  If the goal was to bring democracy to a place ruled by a dictator, that would be a good reason to go to war. But if there was any personal stuff mixed in, that's not cool.  

I think we made a pretty big statement in the beginning, showing everyone we weren't messing around. But after all these years – years! – I just don't see the point anymore. It feels like we're stuck in this endless cycle of fighting, just for the sake of fighting.  

We need a clear end to this, a win, or something. We can't just keep throwing money at a war that's lost its purpose.  We gotta think about our own problems too, you know?  Billions are going overseas when we have poverty, education issues, healthcare…things that need fixing right here at home.  

It's like we're pouring money into this bottomless pit while our own citizens are struggling. It's just not right.  

War shouldn't be a long-term budget item. We need to focus on fixing things here, supporting our people, and not wasting money on a war that's gone on for far too long.

So, there's this question about privacy on Myspace, right? 
Like, what happens when someone looks at your profile and finds something that could, you know, get someone hurt?
I mean, if you post stuff online, it's kinda out there for anyone to see. Like, on Myspace, you gotta be friends with someone to see their profile, but you're choosing to be their friend, so you're giving them permission to see it.

It's a weird situation though, 'cause you can't have someone watching everyone's profiles all the time, right? 
It'd be like picking on the "bad kids" just because they're online. 

But then again, what if someone was looking for something specific?
Like, if they saw something that made them think someone was in danger, wouldn't it be good they found it?

It's a tough call.  I don't have Myspace myself, but I have Facebook, and it freaks me out knowing that creepy people can see my stuff.
I saw this thing on TV where this guy showed how easy it was to find someone's info online. He got a girl's screen name and was chatting with her on IM within a minute, then got her to meet up.
I wouldn't do that, but some people in my classes message me on Facebook even though I don't recognize their names. They already know stuff about me, like my classes, my friends, and even pictures.

It's a bit scary, 'cause you think they know a lot about you. You try to be careful about what you post, but you also want to connect with friends.  It's a balancing act.

I heard my roommate talking about how her high school banned Myspace, which seems kinda messed up.  How can they tell students what they can and can't do online?

Ugh, this whole Iraq War thing just makes me feel so conflicted. It's hard to talk about it without feeling hypocritical, you know? Like, I hate jumping on the bandwagon of people who are all "I was against it from the start."  But honestly, it's just so obvious now that it was a terrible idea.  Everyone knows it, except for those stuck in the administration who can't admit they were wrong. 

I mean, look at the polls!  Everywhere you look –  the US, Iraq, even globally –  people are saying it was a bad call.  Seventy-five to eighty percent think it was a mistake. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of our own troops over there – they all agree it's time to get out.

It's been a mess from the beginning, and pulling out is just going to be another disaster.  There's no easy answer when it comes to the Middle East. It's like a cultural clash, you know? The US and the Middle East are just too different.  This administration, and the ones before it, think they can just force democracy on a place that's not ready for it.  It's like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole.

Sure, Saddam was a bad guy, but invading a country like that has consequences.  It's like quicksand – once you're in, it's hard to get out.

I don't know what to say about it anymore. I see no reason to stay. The administration probably has some fancy reasons why we should stick it out, but I haven't heard anything convincing. If they want to leave gradually, over a year or so, I guess I wouldn't be against it.  But honestly, we should just pull out now. 

I read that eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone within a year, and a quarter of them want us out right now. These are the people we're supposedly saving, trying to help. They're telling us to leave. Maybe they know what's best. At least if we ask them and they say "yes," then we're not to blame if things go south. We'll be like, "Hey, you guys wanted us out."

We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, no matter what we do. But at least leaving would be better than where we are now.

Yeah, listen, I totally think gender stuff is still a big deal in the U.S.  And it's not just about women, either. It's more about the field you're in, you know? Like, overall, I feel women have it tougher. There's this invisible ceiling, even though equality is supposed to be a thing. Sometimes guys get hung up on having a woman as their boss.  Society's been like that for ages! 

So, often women see a job they're totally qualified for, but the board might not pick them because, historically, women aren't seen as top dogs in business.  

It's the same for guys, though, in different ways. Think about staying home with kids. It's super uncommon for dads to be the stay-at-home parent, and people often judge them for it. Society thinks, "Dude, you gotta be the breadwinner, man!" Even if it's working great for them and the wife has the better job, people still look down on it.

And in fashion?  It's tough for straight guys. People might not take them seriously.  Maybe it's because guys into fashion are seen as having a different kind of lifestyle, so folks wonder if they really get "woman" fashion.  

So yeah, I think there's gender discrimination everywhere, depending on what you do. 

Changing it is slow, though. Society's got its ways, and we've definitely come a long way from the 1800s. But change is slow.  We're seeing more women in top roles, more dads at home, and people are slowly getting used to it. It's a process.

I think we just gotta keep promoting the good stuff about people who are stereotyped, not be too pushy. Just show them being awesome, you know?  If you force it, people resist.  We're starting to find a good balance.

Change takes time, man.

So, lemme break this down. They didn't exactly *legalize* it, more like decriminalized it, y'know?  Like, instead of being a full-blown criminal offense, it's more like,  uh, a traffic ticket.  You get a citation, not locked up in the slammer. It's a lighter slap on the wrist.  But, even with that, think about job interviews, background checks - all that jazz. Those kind of repercussions, they still linger, even if it ain't a hardcore criminal charge.  I mean, people worry about that future baggage, especially with something like marijuana. 

The thing is, cops and courts cost a pretty penny.  Arrest, booking, holding cells, court appearances, a lawyer, the whole shebang. It's a money pit!  And towns struggling financially? They're less likely to change their tune, even if it means saving cash in the long run.  I get it, some places are still dead set against marijuana, even if it's just about the bottom line.

Now, Denver's a different story.  They're more open-minded, you know, liberal, whatever word you wanna use.  Makes sense to me.  If they're raking in the dough from somewhere else, maybe they can use it for schools, help out seniors, feed the homeless folks.  Seems like a win-win, right?

Look, I'm not saying we should just let folks blaze up everywhere, in gas stations and whatnot.  There's a line. But the money thing is real.  Plus, it's still kinda taboo, you know?  Imagine everyone just smoking openly, it'd be awkward af.

Now, alcohol's got its own nasty side effects, I ain't denying it.  But marijuana, it messes with people's lives more, y'know?  It's not just about motor skills, it's about the whole vibe.

But honestly, everyone reacts differently.  Some folks can handle it, others, not so much.  It's a tricky thing.

I'd say "maybe" to the Catholic Church.  I mean, there's a lot to like about their traditions, they've been doing things the same way for ages, right? It's good to have roots, but it's also important to be able to change with the times.

The thing is, a lot of Catholics seem to think they *have* to go to church every week, and they're pretty strict about how things are done. Sometimes it feels like the Church judges people who don't follow the rules perfectly, and they don't really welcome people who aren't, well, *perfectly* Catholic.  They don't seem very open to other religions either. 

Take my dad, for example. He was an Episcopalian, and my mom was Catholic. They wouldn't even let them get married in the Catholic Church because of his religion! I mean, isn't loving others one of the biggest Catholic teachings? It seems hypocritical to preach love but then not accept people who are different. 

It's like they tell you to do one thing but then act another way entirely.  Their practices seem so stuck in the past, but they just keep holding on. 

Would allowing priests to marry change things? I personally think it would be a good idea, but I don't think it would stop them from, you know...doing bad things. It's a whole different issue, really.  

It's probably not the marriage that's the problem.  People who hurt kids would probably find a way to do it whether they were married or not. It's just a messed up thing to do.

Man, this whole thing about marriage is a real head-scratcher, you know? I haven't figured out where I stand yet.  It's like walking a tightrope between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage *really* means. It's a minefield,  Trying to nail down a definition without stepping on anyone's toes is tough.

I'm thinking, maybe all civil unions should just be treated the same.  If it's a sacrament, like baptism, the government shouldn't be in the business of giving tax breaks or special treatment based on it.  It's just two people coming together, right?  They shouldn't care if it's a religious ceremony or not.

And with gay marriage, I mean, it just seems like it should be a civil union thing.  Two people, one union.  Simple as that.

Now, if all the states can agree on something sensible,  then maybe it should become federal law. But this whole idea of a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage?  That's just crazy talk! The constitution shouldn't be changed just because some folks are really passionate about it.  It's not like it's a matter of life and death.

Growing up in a Christian household, my views on homosexuality are a bit complicated.  I've got a ton of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily condone their lifestyle, I think everyone should have the right to marry whoever they love.  It's not an issue that should be decided nationally, though. Each state should have the freedom to choose its own stance.  

Think about it: some states are more liberal, others are more conservative.  Democratic states are more likely to support gay marriage, and if you live there, you're pretty much accepting of that.  It's like choosing to live somewhere – you kinda know what to expect.

So, I believe everyone should have equal opportunities, regardless of their sexual orientation.  Legalizing gay marriage should be left up to each state to decide.  Personally, I don't think the president should have the power to impose his views on the entire country. It's not his place to dictate what happens in every state. 

Plus, he's leaving office soon anyway.  If a new president comes in and wants to overturn the ban, it'll just be a back-and-forth battle.  It's best to let each state decide what's right for them – they're the ones who have to live with the consequences.

Um, so basically, I'm saying MySpace is like a public bulletin board. Anything you put on there is meant for everyone to see, not just your friends. You gotta realize that if you post something online, even if it's not under your school's name, anyone can find it, even school officials at home.

So, yeah, I think it's totally fine if they saw something on there that could prevent a school shooting.  I mean, keeping students safe is, like, the school's responsibility, right?  

Now, I get it, if they're constantly snooping through MySpace just to catch kids doing dumb stuff, that's a different story. That's an invasion of privacy. But if they have a reason to believe something bad might happen, I think they're totally justified in looking.

It's kinda like, you wouldn't expect to get away with writing something bad about someone in a school hallway and not getting in trouble, right?  Same kinda thing with the internet.  Everything you post online can come back to bite you later, especially when you're older. 

The bottom line is, if posting on MySpace could save lives or make school a safer place, I think it's worth it. Like, imagine if they saw something that stopped a Columbine situation from happening.  That's gotta be worth it, right?

Ok, so about this whole war thing... see, after nine eleven, I was all for it.  You know, getting back at them, causing some serious chaos. I was riding high on that emotional wave, and honestly, I think we all kind of overlooked the big picture. We just jumped in, unprepared, with no real plan. And now? Well, now I think it backfired spectacularly. I mean, I used to be all for it, but now, I'm totally against it. 

It feels like we haven't accomplished anything.  The people over there, they're stuck fighting amongst themselves.  What good are we doing by being there if they can't even get along with each other?  I'm not saying it's not a tragedy, but I just feel numb about it now.   Truthfully, because of nine eleven, I just don't care about what goes on over there with those people. They're just fighting, tearing each other apart... it's like they don't even care about their own country. 

We went in there blind, clueless about what we were facing. War for them is different, way different from how we experience it. They're savage, and I don't think they're trying to build anything, they just want us out.  And honestly, maybe that's fine. Maybe we should just leave.

We were so hyped up, so caught up in the revenge thing, that we didn't think things through.  We just wanted to lash out, and I think Bush felt pressured to go to war because that's what people wanted.  He probably felt like he had no choice. 

But looking back, I think we should have had a better plan. We didn't know what we were doing, there was no clear strategy. It felt like we lacked unity, like we didn't even know why we were there.  

It was all emotion, anger... and that's what we created over there. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change them. They'll always be like that. And at this point, I don't know if we're making enough progress to justify staying. We're hurting ourselves more than anything.  We can't stay there forever.
